title: Affect Labeling and Emotional Regulation
supports: Shows that putting feelings into words can reduce emotional intensity and support better self-control, underlying the Pressure Dump and Anger ≠ Action tools.

title: Stress Response and Decision-Making
supports: Explains how stress shifts thinking toward fast, reactive systems and away from reflective judgment, supporting the need for Decision Delay and Anger ≠ Action.

title: Allostatic Load and Allostasis: Implications for Neuropsychopharmacology
supports: Describes how chronic stress and ongoing demands create wear-and-tear on the body, backing the focus on pressure load and Silent Load Inventory.

title: Protective and Damaging Effects of Stress Mediators
supports: Shows how long-term activation of the stress system harms cardiovascular and metabolic health, connecting Gate 01 pressure to physical cost.

title: Job Strain as a Risk Factor for Coronary Heart Disease: A Collaborative Meta-Analysis
supports: Links high demands with low control at work to increased heart disease risk, supporting the emphasis on real control and Decision Delay.

title: Stress Signalling Pathways that Impair Prefrontal Cortex Structure and Function
supports: Explains how stress weakens prefrontal brain areas involved in planning and impulse control, backing tools that create gaps between feeling and action.

title: Sleep and Emotion Regulation: Evidence from Functional Neuroimaging
supports: Shows that sleep improves emotional regulation and decision-making, supporting the 24-hour delay guideline for major decisions.

title: Men, Masculinity, and the Contexts of Help Seeking
supports: Examines how masculine norms shape men’s reluctance to seek support, backing the framing and design of Isolation Reality Check.

title: Social Relationships and Health: A Flashpoint for Health Policy
supports: Shows that social connection and perceived support reduce stress and improve health outcomes, supporting the mechanism of Isolation Reality Check.

title: Caregiver Burden and Mental Health Outcomes
supports: Highlights how invisible, ongoing responsibilities contribute to stress and health risks, reinforcing the importance of mapping silent load.
